title: 105_hr1975
content: The Credit Card Consumer Protection Act of 1997 prohibits fees for on-time payments. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act prohibits fees for on-time credit card payments. The Truth in Lending Act prohibits fees imposed on consumers in advance to cover credit card account maintenance costs, regardless of whether credit is extended or not. SEC. 3. FREEZE ON INTEREST RATE TERMS AND FEES ON CANCELED CARDS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include a new subsection (j) that requires advance notice of any increase in interest rates on credit card accounts. The increase cannot take effect until at least 15 days after the accountholder receives notice. Additionally, the increase is not effective for canceled accounts. If the accountholder cancels a credit card account before the billing cycle begins, the interest rate on the outstanding balance cannot exceed the rate before the cancellation. Repayment of the balance will follow the original terms and conditions. The notice of right to cancel an account before an increase in interest rate must include the option to pay off the balance according to the terms in effect before cancellation. SEC. 4. DISCLOSURE OF FEES AND INTEREST RATES ON CREDIT ADVANCES THROUGH THE USE OF 3RD PARTY CHECKS. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include new subsection (l) regarding fees and interest rates on credit advances through the use of 3rd party checks. Creditors are prohibited from providing accountholders with negotiable instruments for credit extensions without meeting notice requirements. The Truth in Lending Act's Section 127 is amended to include new subsection (l) which requires creditors to provide notice to accountholders about transaction fees and interest rates for credit extensions through 3rd party checks. Section 127 of the Truth in Lending Act is further amended to include a new subsection (m) prohibiting creditors from charging over-the-limit fees on credit card accounts under open-end consumer credit plans for extensions of credit approved in advance or at the time of the transaction. Additionally, Section 6 prohibits 2-cycle billing. SEC. 6. PROHIBITION ON 2-CYCLE BILLING. This section amends the Truth in Lending Act to prohibit 2-cycle billing on credit card accounts under open-end consumer credit plans. Section 127(c) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to include an additional notice requirement for credit card applications offering teaser rates for introductory periods of less than 1 year. The amendment to Section 127(c) of the Truth in Lending Act requires credit card applications with teaser rates for introductory periods of less than 1 year to disclose the fixed annual percentage rate that will apply after the introductory period ends. The disclosure for credit card applications with variable annual percentage rates must include information about the permanent rate that will apply after the introductory period ends. The disclosure required for credit card applications with variable annual percentage rates must include information about the permanent rate that will apply after the introductory period ends. The disclosure should be clear and prominent, similar to the disclosure of the introductory period's annual percentage rate.
